KUPU AND US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) ARE LONGTIME PARTNERS IN PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR HANDS-ON SERVICE LEARNING (INTERNSHIPS) TO YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS. THESE OPPORTUNITIES EDUCATE, TRAIN, MENTOR, AND ENGAGE THE NEXT GENERATION OF NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS THROUGH HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES THAT ALSO PROVIDE A CRITICAL SERVICE TO USFWS SITES THROUGHOUT THE PACIFIC, INCLUDING KAUA I, OAHU, MAUI, HAWAI I ISLAND, MIDWAY ATOLL, AMERICAN SAMOA, GUAM, AND THE COMMONWEALTH OF NORTHERN MARIANAS ISLANDS (CNMI).

AMERICAN CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE (ACE), A NON-PROFIT CONSERVATION CORPS, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS), IS SEEKING FIVE BIOLOGY SUPPORT MEMBERS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE BIOLOGY PROGRAM ALONGSIDE EASTERN MASSACHUSETTS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX STAFF. DURING THEIR TERMS, ACE MEMBERS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO WETLAND AND UPLAND HABITAT AND RARE SPECIES MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS. THEY WILL SUPPORT INVENTORY, MONITORING, AND MANAGEMENT OF AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES, MIGRATORY BIRDS, AND INVASIVE SPECIES, AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TO MANAGEMENT OF NESTING PIPING PLOVERS AND TERNS.

GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE SEEKS TO CONTINUE A HIGHLY PRODUCTIVE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MANY REFUGES THAT COLLECTIVELY FORM THE SOUTHEAST IDAHO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX. ANNUALLY, GBI WILL SEEK TO RECRUIT ONE OR TWO BIOLOGICAL TECHNICIANS PER REFUGE TO SUPPORT AND IMPLEMENT PROJECTS FOCUSED ON INVASIVE SPECIES TREATMENT AND HABITAT RESTORATION. TECHNICIANS WILL GAIN A BROAD UNDERSTANDING OF THE INVASIVE SPECIES ISSUES FACING THE INTERMOUNTAIN WEST, AND THE TOOLS METHODS AVAILABLE FOR PREVENTION, SURVEILLANCE, DETECTION MONITORING, CONTROL, AND RESTORATION. THESE PROJECTS SPAN HABITATS (SHRUB-STEPPE, GRASSLAND, WETLAND, AND RIPARIAN) AND ENCOMPASS THREE CATEGORIES OF TOOLS AVAILABLE FOR INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL (MECHANICAL, CHEMICAL, BIOLOGICAL). FURTHERMORE, THE TECHNICIANS WILL BE EXPOSED TO VARIOUS ELEMENTS OF THE HABITAT RESTORATION PROCESS INCLUDING TRAINING ON PREVENTION BIOSECURITY  THE AFOREMENTIONED METHODS OF INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL  NATIVE GRASS, TREE, AND FORB RESTORATION  LONG-TERM VEGETATION MONITORING  AND NOXIOUS WEED MAPPING. RESULTS FROM THESE ACTIVITIES WILL PROVIDE REFUGE MANAGERS AND RESEARCHERS GREATER ACCESS TO CURRENT DATA TO MAKE AID IN DECISION-MAKING PROCESSES. ADDITIONALLY, RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL ENHANCE WILDLIFE HABITAT AND MAKE THESE REFUGES MORE DESIRABLE PLACES FOR THE PUBIC TO VISIT AND ENJOY. GBI IS REQUESTING  137,942.66 TO SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION IN FY24 AND FY25.

AMERICAN CONSERVATION EXPERIENCE, A NONPROFIT CONSERVATION CORPS, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IS SEEKING ONE INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL FELLOW TO HELP WITH A BURN AREA EMERGENCY RESTORATION PROJECT TREATING AND REMOVING NOXIOUS WEEDS FROM PIXLEY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. THIS POSITION WILL HELP FWS REALIZE THE MISSION AT PIXLEY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE THROUGH INVASIVE PLANT REMOVAL AND HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE UPLAND UNITS OF THE PIXLEY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX. THE FELLOW WILL BE LED BY A TEAM LEAD TO REMOVE THE INVASIVE SPECIES USING VARIOUS MECHANICAL AND CHEMICAL METHODS, CONDUCT BIOLOGICAL MONITORING, AND HELP WITH ENDANGERED SPECIES TRAPPING. ONCE THE TREATMENT OF THE INVASIVE SPECIES HAS BEEN CONDUCTED, THE FELLOW WILL PLANT NATIVE SEEDS TO RESTORE THE VEGETATION.

THE PARTNERSHIP FOR PROVIDENCE PARKS AND THE DEPARTMENT OF PROVIDENCE PARKS HAS BEEN WORKING CLOSELY WITH STAFF IN YOUR RHODE ISLAND NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND COASTAL PROGRAM OFFICES TO BRING A CONSERVATION MESSAGE, AS WELL AS AN AWARENESS OF THE SERVICE, TO THE URBAN NEIGHBORHOODS OF PROVIDENCE  WHERE FAMILIES LIVE AND WORK AND PLAY. PROVIDENCE IS ONE OF THE MOST DIVERSE CITIES IN THE UNITED STATES. THE NEED FOR A DIRECT CONSERVATION MESSAGE IN THIS URBAN ENVIRONMENT IS ESPECIALLY SIGNIFICANT SINCE THE POPULATION OF PROVIDENCE HAS A 28  POVERTY RATE, WITH 23  OF THE POPULATION UNDER THE AGE OF 18 (U.S. CENSUS BUREAU). IT IS CRITICAL TO REACH THESE SCHOOLCHILDREN AND FAMILIES WHERE THEY LIVE AND WORK, SINCE MOST DO NOT HAVE THE RESOURCES TO TRAVEL TO RURAL NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES AND ZOOS - AND EXPOSE THEM TO THE SERVICES CONSERVATION AND WILDLIFE MESSAGE. THE FOCUS OF THIS PARTNERSHIP HAS BEEN TO PROVIDE THE EXPERTISE TO TIE IN THE PARK SYSTEM AND THEIR FRIENDS GROUPS, ALONG WITH NON- GOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS, WITH A BROADER SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE AND ASSIST THEM IN ENGAGING NEIGHBORHOODS, VOLUNTEERS, SCHOOLS AND FAMILIES IN LASTING WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ETHICS. AS SUCH, WE HAVE BEEN WORKING COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE SERVICE AND NUMEROUS OTHER PARTNERS TO COLLECTIVELY SUPPORT AN URBAN COORDINATOR POSITION, WHICH ALLOWS US TO PROVIDE WILDLIFE-RELATED PUBLIC PROGRAMS, WILDLIFE HABITAT ENHANCEMENT, OUTDOOR ENGAGEMENT PROGRAMS WITH SCHOOLS, AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAMS AND TRAINING TO TEACHERS TO OFFER ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION IN THEIR OWN CLASSROOMS.

THE ARCTIC YOUTH AMBASSADORS PROGRAM ELEVATES YOUTH VOICES IN INTERNATIONAL ARENAS, EMPOWERS FUTURE ARCTIC LEADERS, AND BUILDS GREATER UNDERSTANDING ABOUT LIFE IN THE ARCTIC. BY ADDING THEIR VOICES TO A GLOBAL CONVERSATION ABOUT HOW TO SUSTAIN OUR COMMUNITIES, CULTURES, AND THE ENVIRONMENT, THEY LEAD SOLUTIONS FOR OUR HOMES IN THE CHANGING ARCTIC. THE PROGRAM BRINGS DIVERSE YOUTH FROM ACROSS ALASKA TO SERVE AS AMBASSADORS FOR THEIR COMMUNITIES AND BUILD AWARENESS OF ARCTIC ISSUES AT CONVENINGS AROUND THE WORLD. THEY ARE INVOLVED IN MEETINGS IN THE UNITED STATES AND ABROAD, SHARING THEIR PERSPECTIVES AS YOUTH FROM ALASKA. THE LIGHT DETECTION AND RANGING (LIDAR) MONITORING PROJECT ON REFUGES IN THE SOUTHEAST INTEGRATES THE LATEST FOREST VEGETATION AND ECOSYSTEM SURVEYING TECHNOLOGY INTO LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THE TLS TECHNOLOGY ACCURATELY MAPS AND MEASURES FOREST VEGETATION AND STRUCTURE.

MCC CREWS WILL CUT DOWN TREES THAT SHOULDN-T BE THERE ANYWAY. THESE CONIFER TREES ARE ONLY GROWING IN THAT AREA DUE TO LACK OF THE NATURAL FIRE REGIME. THE CREW WILL CUT THE TOPS OF THE TREES OFF THE TRUNKS (INTO MANAGEABLE SIZES TO MOVE) AND WILL USE THIS SLASH TO PROTECT ASPEN GROUPINGS. AS THE TRUNKS GET TOO LARGE TO MOVE, THEY WILL JUST BE LEFT IN PLACE TO ADD BACK TO THE HABITAT.SOME OF THE BIGGER TREES CAN BE GIRDLED (IF THEY ARE TOO BIG FOR THE MCC CREW) WHICH WILL EVENTUALLY KILL THEM AND MAKE THEM INTO NESTING TREES FOR CAVITY NESTERS. THIS IS ALL HABITAT WORK. REMOVING INVASIVE CONIFERS (ONLY THERE DUE TO LACK OF THE NATURAL FIRE REGIME) FROM NATIVE GRASSLANDS. PROTECTING ASPEN TREES THAT ARE CURRENTLY BEING OVER BROWSED BY ELK AND DEER. BRINGING BACK ASPEN GROVES WHICH ARE ALL AGING OUT DUE TO LACK OF NATURAL WILDFIRES.

ONGOING WATER MANAGEMENT EFFORTS THAT MITIGATE EXTREME FLOWS TO REDUCE FLOODING IMPACTS KEEPERS OF THE FISHERY IN THE OJIBWE CULTURE. HERE WE PROPOSE TO ASSESS MOVEMENT OF LAKE STURGEON, AS WELL AS SEVERAL OTHER NATIVE SPECIES OF CONCERN (E.G., BIGMOUTH BUFFALO, CHANNEL CATFISH, ETC.), TO ENSURE THERE IS SUFFICIENT CONNECTIVITY IN THE RED RIVER WATERSHED TO ALLOW COMPLETED LIFE CYCLES. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE TO  (1) MONITOR TARGET SPECIES MOVEMENTS  (2) EVALUATE TIMING OF MOVEMENTS  AND (3) USE THESE DATA TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS ON ON INFRASTRUCTURE THROUGHOUT THE RED RIVER WATERSHED HAVE LED TO CONCERNS ABOUT FISH PASSAGE OVER EXISTING DAMS AS WELL THROUGH, OR AROUND, CURRENT AND PENDING WATER DIVERSION PROJECTS. MANY OF THESE SPECIES ARE BOTH ECOLOGICALLY AND CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT. LAKE STURGEON RECOVERY AND REINTRODUCTION EFFORTS ACCENTUATE THE LINKAGE BETWEEN ECOLOGY AND CULTURE. THIS SPECIES IS VIEWED AS A SENTINEL INDICATOR OF A PROPERLY FUNCTIONING ECOSYSTEM BECAUSE THEY TYPICALLY NEED LONG REACHES OF RIVER TO COMPLETE THEIR LIFE CYCLE. LAKE STURGEON ARE ALSO REGARDED AS SPIRITUAL FUTURE WATER MANAGEMENT IN THE CONTEXT OF ECOLOGICALLY AND CULTURALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES. THE TELEMETRY NETWORK, CONSISTING OF   250 LISTENING STATIONS, SPANS NEARLY THE ENTIRETY OF THE RED RIVER AND EXTENDS INTO THE ASSINIBOINE RIVER AND LAKE WINNIPEG TO ENSURE MOVEMENTS ARE CAPTURED ADEQUATELY (FIGURE 1). TARGET SPECIES BEING TRACKED IN THE RED RIVER INCLUDE PRIMARILY LAKE STURGEON, BIGMOUTH BUFFALO, CHANNEL CATFISH, AND FRESHWATER DRUM, BUT ADDITIONAL SPECIES ARE BEING MONITORED AND WILL BE INCLUDED IN ANALYSES WHEN THEY ARE PRESENT IN THE RED RIVER (TABLE 1). THESE SPECIES ARE CULTURALLY, ECOLOGICALLY, AND ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT THROUGHOUT THE BASIN AND ALSO REPRESENT A RANGE OF MOVEMENT STRATEGIES THAT WILL HELP US BETTER UNDERSTAND FISH MOVEMENTS, ESPECIALLY THROUGH AND AROUND THE FARGO MOORHEAD DIVERSION AND ASSOCIATED MITIGATION PROJECTS CURRENTLY UNDER CONSTRUCTION OR CONSIDERATION.THIS AWARD WILL EMPLOY ONE NON PLC PLACEMENT GRADUATE STUDENT IN A MULTI YEAR PROJECT. THE NON PLC PLACEMENT WILL NOT BE ELIGIBLE TO ACCRUE CREDITABLE HOURS UNDER THE PUBLIC LANDS CORPS ACT.

THE PUBLIC LANDS TRANSPORTATION FELLOWS PROGRAM, HEREIN REFERRED TO AS PLTF, PROVIDES FELLOWSHIPS TO OUTSTANDING GRADUATES IN A TRANSPORTATION-RELATED FIELD TO WORK DIRECTLY WITH STAFF OF FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES ON KEY VISITOR TRANSPORTATION ISSUES. THE PLTF PROGRAM BEGAN IN 2012 AND WAS MODELED AFTER THE VERY SUCCESSFUL TRANSPORTATION SCHOLARS PROGRAM MANAGED BY THE NATIONAL PARK FOUNDATION (NPF) THAT SERVES THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS). THE PLTF PROGRAM GIVES RECENT GRADUATES (SOMETIMES CURRENT STUDENTS) IN A TRANSPORTATION RELATED ENGINEERING, PLANNING, OR RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY FOR CAREER DEVELOPMENT AND PUBLIC SERVICE. SUCCESSFUL APPLICANTS ARE PLACED AT A FEDERAL LAND UNIT FACING A TRANSPORTATION ISSUE TO FACILITATE A TRANSPORTATION PLANNING OR IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT. A FELLOW IS ASSIGNED TO WORK DIRECTLY WITH STAFF AT A UNIT OR HEADQUARTERS/REGION/FIELD OFFICE. THE ASSIGNED PROJECTS HELP THE LAND UNITS DEVELOP TRANSPORTATION SOLUTIONS THAT PRESERVE VALUABLE RESOURCES AND ENHANCE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE. THE PROGRAM HAS THREE GOALS, WHICH ARE TO: "ENCOURAGE EMERGING TRANSPORTATION PROFESSIONALS TO PURSUE THEIR CAREER SERVING FEDERAL LANDS. "PROVIDE MUCH-NEEDED TRANSPORTATION EXPERTISE TO FLMA UNITS AND REGIONS TO HELP THEM ADDRESS CRITICAL TRANSPORTATION ISSUES. "SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION OF VIABLE ALTERNATIVE TRANSPORTATION FOR VISITORS TO FLMAS. THE USFWS HAS A LIMITED TRANSPORTATION STAFF (13 PEOPLE FOR 850 MILLION ACRES OF MANAGED LANDS AND WATERS) AND ONLY $30 MILLION PER YEAR TO MANAGE THE TRANSPORTATION NETWORK. THEREFORE, THE FELLOWS DEEP-DIVE INTO THE COMPLEX TRANSPORTATION ISSUES THAT WOULD HAVE COST THE USFWS MILLIONS OF DOLLARS IN ADDITIONAL CONTRACTS, PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND TRAVEL COSTS TO COMPLETE. QUITE SIMPLY, THIS MISSION CRITICAL WORK WOULD NOT BE DONE WITHOUT THEM. THE 2022 CLASS OF FELLOWS WILL INCLUDE THREE REGULAR FELLOWS. THE FELLOWS WILL BE EMPLOYEES OF THE WESTERN TRANSPORTATION INSTITUTE AT MONTANA STATE UNIVERSITY BOZEMAN, BUT WILL BE STATIONED AT THE FOLLOWING LOCATIONS: "RIDGEFIELD NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR) IN VANCOUVER, WASHINGTON "DESERT NWR IN LAS VEGAS, NEVADA "CRAB ORCHARD NWR IN CARBONDALE, ILLINOIS THE FELLOWS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ATTENDING AN ORIENTATION, FOLLOWING THE SCOPES OF WORK THAT HAVE BEEN CREATED FOR EACH OF THEIR REFUGES, WORKING WITH A MENTOR, ATTENDING MONTHLY CALLS WITH THE MENTORS, PRESENTING AT A POSTER SESSION AT THE ANNUAL TRANSPORTATION RESEARCH BOARD (TRB) MEETING, DOING A HEADQUARTERS AND REGIONAL OFFICE ROTATION, CREATING A FINAL REPORT, AND PROVIDING A FINAL WEBINAR. THIS PROJECT ALSO CONSISTS OF THE ADMINISTRATION/PROMOTION OF THE PROGRAM, CREATION OF THE SCOPES OF WORK AND ORIENTATION MATERIALS, SELECTION/HIRING OF FELLOWS, ORIENTATION LOGISTICS, MENTORSHIP TO THE FELLOWS, SITE VISIT(S) TO EACH OF THE LOCATIONS, MAINTENANCE OF THE PLTF WEBPAGES, AND THE BI-WEEKLY TRAINING EBLAST.

HAF'S LONG TERM GOAL FOR THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD A STRONG NUMBER OF INSPIRED, SKILLED, CULTURALLY,  ETHNICALLY, AND ECONOMICALLY DIVERSE YOUNG PEOPLE WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED NATURAL RESOURCE CAREERS WITH  THE USFWS HQ AND REFUGES NATIONWIDE, RESULTING IN A DIVERSE WORKFORCE OF CONSERVATIONISTS THAT IS  TRULY REFLECTIVE OF THE REGIONAL POPULATION. PROJECT OBJECTIVES THROUGH THIS PROJECT:  1. SIX USFWS INTERNS, AGES 18-30 (UP TO 35 FOR VETERANS), WILL BE INTRODUCED TO NATURAL  RESOURCE CAREERS THROUGH A 38-WEEK PAID FELLOWSHIPS (UP TO 40 HOURS PER WEEK) INVOLVING  HANDS-ON WORK WITH, AND TRAINING BY NATURAL RESOURCE PROFESSIONALS EMPLOYED BY THE USFWS  STAFF AT TIER 3 URBAN REFUGES.  2. THE INTERNS WILL CONTINUE VARIOUS RESEARCH, COMMUNICATIONS AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES THROUGH  HIS/HER WORK ASSIGNMENT AT USFWS AND THROUGH INFORMAL AND/OR FORMAL TRAINING SESSIONS  PROVIDED BY USFWS EMPLOYEES.  3. THE INTERNS WILL RECEIVE SPECIALIZED TRAINING, MENTORING AND ONGOING SUPPORT FROM HAF TO  EFFECTIVELY CARRY OUT THE ASSIGNMENT AND TO BUILD OR ENHANCE SKILLS IN A MANNER CONSISTENT  WITH REGION PRIORITIES.  4. THE INTERNS WILL GAIN AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CAREERS IN NATURAL RESOURCES  AND WILL BUILD SKILLS AND EXPERIENCE REQUIRED FOR SUCCESS IN THESE CAREERS.  5. USFWS WILL EXPAND ITS POOL OF DIVERSE CANDIDATES AVAILABLE FOR FUTURE EMPLOYMENT  OPPORTUNITIES AND WILL INCREASE ITS VISIBILITY AND THE KNOWLEDGE OF ITS WORK AMONG DIVERSE  VISITORS AND CONSTITUENTS, WITH A PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON URBAN AUDIENCES.  6. BY ENGAGING DIVERSE STUDENTS IN THESE ASSIGNMENTS USFWS WILL EXPAND ITS ABILITY TO  DIVERSIFY THEIR WORKFORCE IN THE SHORT AND LONG-TERM.

OVERVIEW: CONSERVATION CORPS OF MINNESOTA AND IOWA WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE USFWS -TAMARAC NWR TO TREAT INVASIVE SPECIES WITHIN THE REFUGE BOUNDARIES. OUR GOAL IS TO CONTROL INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES IN AN EFFORT TO RESTORE WETLAND AND UPLAND HABITATS ON TAMARAC NWR. FUNDS WILL BE SPENT ON A FIELD CREW TO TREAT INVASIVE PLANTS, THROUGH THE USE OF HERBICIDES, ON AT DESIGNATED SITES OF TAMARAC NWR.PROJECT NARRATIVE:THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE CONTROLLING INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES (PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE, COMMON TANSY, WILD PARSNIP AND SIBERIAN PEASHRUB) THROUGH HERBICIDE TREATMENTS BY A FIELD CREW ON TAMARAC NWR. THE FIELD CREW WILL BE PROVIDED THROUGH A CONTRACT WITH THE CONSERVATION CORPS OF MINNESOTA AND IOWA (CCM). THESE CREWS ARE COMPRISED OF 5-6 INDIVIDUALS, INCLUDING A CREW LEADER. THESE CREWS TYPICALLY COST $6,000 - $8,000 PER WEEK AND THE CREW WILL BE NEEDED FOR TWO WEEKS. FIELD WORK WILL INITIALLY FOCUS ON CONTROLLING APPROXIMATELY 55 ACRES OF PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE AT THREE DIFFERENT LOCATIONS WITHIN TAMARAC NWR. TREATMENT OF PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE WILL BE THE FIRST PRIORITY BECAUSE THE SITES ARE ON FLOATING SEDGE BOGS AND REQUIRE THE USE OF A CREW. ONCE THE TREATMENT OF PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE HAS BEEN COMPLETED, FIELD EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON TREATING COMMON TANSY, WILD PARSNIP AND SIBERIAN PEASHRUB.PROJECT OBJECTIVES: QUANTIFIABLE OBJECTIVES INCLUDE TREATING APPROXIMATELY 55 ACRES OF INVASIVE SPECIES (PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE) INFESTATIONS IN THE TARGET GEOGRAPHY. ONCE THE TREATMENT OF PURPLE LOOSESTRIFE HAS BEEN COMPLETED, FIELD EFFORTS WILL FOCUS ON TREATING COMMON TANSY, WILD PARSNIP AND SIBERIAN PEASHRUB AS THE AVAILABLE REMAINING FUNDS/TIME ALLOW.

MANY UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES OF COLOR REMAIN UNDER-REPRESENTED IN THE FEDERAL WORKFORCE. FEDERAL AGENCIES SUCH AS THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ARE SLOWLY MAKING PROGRESS TO BUILD A FEDERAL WORKFORCE THAT DRAWS FROM THE FULL DIVERSITY OF THE US POPULATION. HISPANIC ACCESS FOUNDATION'S VISION FOR THEIR MANO PROJECT INITIATIVE IS TO BUILD A STRONG NUMBER OF INSPIRED, SKILLED, CULTURALLY, ETHINICALLY, AND ECONOMICALLY DIVERSE YOUNG PEOPLE WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED NATURAL RESOURCE INTERNSHIPS WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. THESE INTERNSHIPS COULD LEAD TO A POTENTIAL CAREER WITH THE SERVICE, RESULTING IN A DIVERSE WORKFORCE OF CONSERVATIONISTS THAT IS TRULY REFLECTIVE OF THE COMMUNITY AND OVERALL POPULATION.OUR OBJECTIVE FOR THIS PROGRAM ALIGNS WITH THE GOVERNMENT-WIDE STRATEGIC PLAN TO ADVANCE DIVERSITY, EQUITY, INCLUSION, AND ACCESSIBILITY DEIA IN THE FEDERAL WORKFORCE. OUR PROGRAM WOULD SPECIALLY TARGET THREE DEIA PRIORITIES: 1)PROMOTING PAID INTERNSHIPS BY REMOVING BARRIERS FOR LOW-INCOME AND FIRST GENERATION PROFESSIONALS AND REDUCING RELIANCE ON UNPAID INTERNSHIPS AND EXPANDING PAID INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNTIES; 2) PARTNERSHIPS AND RECRUITMENT: PARTNERING WITH HISPANIC ACCESS MANO PROJECT TO RECRUIT STUDENTS, PEOPLE OF COLOR FOR DEVELOPMENTAL INTERNSHIPS TO BUILD A MORE DIVERSE PIPELINE INTO PUBLIC SERVICE; AND 3) PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND ADVANCEMENT: ADVANCING EQUITIY AND TRANSPARENCY IN PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNTIES.

THIS AWARD WILL IDENTIFY POPULATIONS OF CYLINDROPUNTIA VIRIDFLORA AND ASSESS THEIR ABUNDANCE, HEALTH, AND STATUS, THIS SPECIES IS A NEW MEXICO STATE ENDANGERED PLANT, BUT IT IS NOT YET PETITIONED FOR FEDERAL LISTING. KNOWN POPULATIONS ARE SMALL, ISOLATED, AND DECLINING. THERE ARE 37 PLANTS, MOSTLY IN POOR CONDITION (STRESSED BY DISEASE), AT THE BLM SANTA CRUZ RIVER POPULATION, AND THE POPULATION IN THE CITY OF SANTA FE IS REPORTED TO HAVE DECLINED TO APPROXIMATELY 10 PLANTS. THIS DATA SUGGESTS THAT THIS SPECIES IS CRITICALLY IMPERILED WITH EXTINCTION (AND POTENTIALLY ALREADY FUNCTIONALLY EXTINCT); HOWEVER, BOTANISTS HAVE REPORTED SEEING THIS SPECIES FROM HIGHWAY 285 IN THE PUEBLO OF POJOAQUE. ADDITIONAL POPULATIONS ALSO LIKELY EXIST WITHIN NAMBE PUEBLO AND TESUQUE PUEBLO. THESE THREE PUEBLOS OCCUPY THE MAJORITY OF LANDS BETWEEN THE SANTA FE AND SANTA CRUZ RIVER POPULATIONS. RANGE-WIDE SURVEYS TO ASSESS THE EXTENT, POPULATION COUNT, ABUNDANCE, AND HEALTH STATUS OF THIS SPECIES ARE NEEDED TO DETERMINE EXTINCTION RISK AND IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE RECOVERY INTERVENTIONS. THIS AWARD WILL PLACE A INDIAN YOUTH SERVICE CORPS CREW OF 3, ONE CREW LEADER, AND ONE ASSISTANT CREW LEADER TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT.

THE COMPREHENSIVE CONSERVATION PLAN (CCP) FOR LACREEK NWR STATES ONE REFUGE OBJECTIVE AS SEEDING A MINIMUM OF 100 ACRES/YEAR OF DEGRADED PRAIRIE TO NATIVE GRASSES, SEDGES, AND FORBS TO COMPLETE PRAIRIE RECONSTRUCTION. THE CCP ALSO STATES THAT A MINIMUM OF 100 ACRES/YEAR OF EXISTING PRAIRIE WILL BE IMPROVED BY SEEDING WITH NATIVE VEGETATION. IN ACCORDANCE WITH REGIONAL PRIORITIES, LACREEK NWR AND CREW MEMBERS WILL COLLECT NATIVE SEEDS AND RESTORE PRAIRIE ON SERVICE LANDS TO THE BENEFIT OF NATIVE WILDLIFE, INCLUDING MONARCH BUTTERFLIES AND OTHER ENDEMIC POLLINATORS. LACREEK NWR HAS A SUCCESSFUL HISTORY OF IMPLEMENTING A SUCCESSFUL PRESCRIBED FIRE AND PRAIRIE RECONSTRUCTION PROGRAM, WHICH REDUCES NON-NATIVE VEGETATION AND ALLOWS NATIVE GRASSES AND FORBS TO RECOLONIZE. APPROXIMATELY EIGHT PRESCRIBED FIRE UNITS WILL BE READY FOR IMPLEMENTATION DURING THE PROPOSED PROJECT TIME FRAME AND CREW MEMBERS WILL BE AN INTEGRAL PART OF THIS PROJECT. IN THE ABSENCE OF A REFUGE BIOLOGIST, THE CREW WILL ASSIST REFUGE MANAGEMENT WITH MANDATORY WATERFOWL PAIR COUNTS AND WETLAND ASSESSMENTS. THIS IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT THE NATURAL HISTORY AND WETLAND SELECTION OF GRASSLAND/WETLAND NESTING WATERFOWL. THIS AWARD WILL PLACE A SIX PERSON CONSERVATION CREW.

STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOICATION WILL PLACE 2 INTERNS TO ACCOMPANY OUR STAFF AND ASSIST WITH BACKCOUNTRY FISHERY SURVEYS OF DOZENS OF LAKES AND STREAMS IN THE WIND RIVER MOUNTAINS. THE MISSION OF OUR OFFICE IS TO ASSIST THE EASTERN SHOSHONE AND NORTHERN ARAPAHO TRIBES WITH ALL THINGS FISH AND WILDLIFE RELATED TO THE WIND RIVER INDIAN RESERVATION, AN INCREDIBLE LANDSCAPE OF OVER 2 MILLION ACRES. DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BACKPACKING INTO REMOTE WILDERNESS AT HIGH ELEVATION (8,000 TO 12,000 FEET) FOR 5 TO 10-DAY TRIPS WITH THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF SAMPLING LAKES AND STREAMS USING STANDARD FISHING GEAR. THE GOAL IS TO ASSESS THE SPECIES AND CONDITIONS OF CATCHABLE FISH PRESENT AND TO COLLECT GENETIC SAMPLES FROM NATIVE CUTTHROAT TROUT. INTERNS WILL WILL EXPERIENCE ALL THE LOWS AND HIGHS OF REMOTE COUNTRY INCLUDING LONG ARDUOUS HIKES IN RUGGED TERRAIN, MOSQUITOES AND BLACK FLIES, INCLEMENT WEATHER, SORE FEET, THE JOYS OF CONNECTION TO THE NATURAL AND PRISTINE WORLD, THE SATISFACTION OF A HARD-EARNED JOB WELL DONE, AND THE CAMARADERIE THAT COMES FROM WORKING CLOSELY TOGETHER WITH PEERS.  A TYPICAL TRIP WILL INCLUDE 1-3 ADDITIONAL FWS STAFF, WORKING 8-12 HOURS PER DAY AT HIGH ELEVATIONS IN 70-80F DAYTIME HIGHS TO 30SF AT NIGHT. RAIN SHOWERS ARE SPORADIC, BUT CAN OCCUR DAILY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDENT CONSERVATION ASSOCIATION INTERNSHIP IS TO EXECUTE GEOSPATIAL DATA MANAGEMENT UPDATES, FIELD VALIDATION, AND ASSIGNMENT OF WETLAND ATTRIBUTION AND FUNCTIONAL CLASSIFICATIONS TO STANDARDIZE, MERGE, AND UPDATE THE WETLAND INVENTORY FOR AREAS IN ALASKA (PRIMARILY THE ANCHORAGE COMMUTING AREA) IN A MANNER THAT IS ACCEPTABLE AND COMPATIBLE WITH THE NATIONAL WETLAND INVENTORY (NWI), THE FEDERAL STANDARD FOR WETLAND MAPPING.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO FUND MULTIPLE PROJECT SEGMENTS THROUGH YOUTH INTERNSHIPS AT THE SOUTHEAST IDAHO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX.   
THE FIRST PROJECT SEGMENT WILL PLACE AN AMERICORPS INTERN WHO WILL BE CONDUCTING ON-THE-GROUND WORK: RECORDING DATA ON SWAN SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS, COLLECTING CONTAMINANTS AND GENETICS SAMPLES, AND ASSISTING REFUGE BIOLOGISTS WITH CAPTURE AND HANDLING OF THE BIRDS. THE ANTICIPATED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE DETERMINING WHETHER FIELD DATA SUPPORTS EITHER OF THE TWO LEADING HYPOTHESIS FOR POPULATION DECLINE: (1) INBREEDING DEPRESSION AS A CONSEQUENCE OF LIMITED GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND (2) EXPOSURE TO OR BIOACCUMULATION OF A CONTAMINANT THAT NEGATIVELY AFFECTS REPRODUCTION.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT SEGMENT IS TO IDENTIFY THE CAUSE(S) OF DECLINE OF THE IDAHO FLOCK OF GREATER YELLOWSTONE TRUMPETER SWANS, WHICH LARGELY BREEDS ON THREE REFUGES IN THE SOUTHEAST IDAHO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX (BEAR LAKE, CAMAS, AND GRAYS LAKE).

1. TWO YOUNG ADULTS, AGE 18-35, WILL BE INTRODUCED TO NATURAL RESOURCE CAREERS THROUGH 25-WEEK
PAID INTERNSHIPS INVOLVING HANDS-ON WORK WITH, AND TRAINING BY, NATURAL RESOURCE
PROFESSIONALS EMPLOYED BY THE USFWS.

5. USFWS WILL EXPAND ITS POOL OF DIVERSE CANDIDATES AVAILABLE FOR FUTURE EMPLOYMENT

VISITORS AND CONSTITUENTS IN THE PACIFIC SOUTHWEST REGION.

SAN DIEGO GLOBAL WILDLIFE RANGERS.

THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT SAN DIEGO ZOO GLOBAL⿿S WILDLIFE RANGERS PROGRAM WITH LOCAL YMCA FACILITIES DURING THE SUMMER AND THROUGH THE SCHOOL YEAR WITH ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS SURROUNDING THE SAN DIEGO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES. THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE 650 SUMMER CAMP CHILDREN FROM 10 YMCA FACILITIES WITH1.5 HOURS OF ENGAGING ACTIVITIES WITH DR. ZOOLITTLE AND LIVE ANIMALS FROM THE ZOO⿿S COLLECTION, FOLLOWED BY A 2-HOUR FIELD TRIP TO THE REFUGE WHERE THEY WORK WITH REFUGE PARK RANGERS TO RESTORE NATIVE HABITATS AND OBSERVE LOCAL WILDLIFE.  THE 10 YMCA FACILITIES ARE IN COMMUNITIES THAT NEIGHBOR THE SAN DIEGO, SAN DIEGO BAY AND TIJUANA SLOUGH NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES, DEMONSTRATING THE VALUE OF THESE REFUGES AS A COMMUNITY ASSET AND A STEPPING STONE TO ENGAGEMENT.  DURING THE SCHOOL YEAR, SAN DIEGO ZOO WILL BRING THEIR WILDLIFE RANGER PROGRAM TO 10 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN SOUTH BAY SAN DIEGO. THE WILDLIFE RANGER PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE AN ALL SCHOOL ASSEMBLY (REACHING OVER 1,500 STUDENTS PER SCHOOL), A CLASSROOM PRESENTATION AND A FIELD TRIP FOR ALL FIFTH GRADE STUDENTS (2,000 STUDENTS) TO THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE.

SAN DIEGO AUDUBON SOCIETY SHARE OUR SHORES.
THE SAN DIEGO AUDUBON SOCIETY SHARE OUR SHORES PROGRAM PROVIDES STUDENTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO DEVELOP A DEEPER RELATIONSHIP WITH NATURE BY VISITING THEIR LOCAL NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE.  THE PROGRAM IS CREATING A CONSERVATION LEGACY THROUGH THEIR COMMITMENT TO WORK WITH TEACHERS FROM THE SOUTH BAY UNION SCHOOL DISTRICT AND THROUGH THEIR UNIQUE USE OF THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AS A BOTH A CLASSROOM AND BIOLOGICAL FIELD STATION.   THROUGH THIS GRANT, SAN DIEGO AUDUBON SOCIETY WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AS AN OUTDOOR LEARNING CLASSROOM FOR OVER 1,600 STUDENTS.  SAN DIEGO AUDUBON SOCIETY PROVIDES HANDS-ON LEARNING BY TAPPING THE NATURAL CURIOSITY OF YOUNG STUDENTS ABOUT THE NATIVE WILDLIFE IN SAN DIEGO BAY AND BY RESTORING HABITATS ON PUBLIC LANDS.  THROUGH LEARNING AND NATIVE PLANTINGS, THEY DEVELOP A LIFELONG INTEREST IN ACCESS TO THE OUTDOORS.  IMPERIAL BEACH BORDERS THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND SDAS IS HELPING THE REFUGE BE A GREAT NEIGHBOR BY SHOWCASING THE REFUGE AS AN ASSET TO THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES FOR OUTDOOR RECREATION AND EXPANDING LINES OF COMMUNICATION WITH EDUCATIONAL LEADERS IN THE COMMUNITY.
